Existing pre: k serves select students: Not all children attend public pre-kindergarten, but Texas school districts have been required to offer pre-K to certain students since 1985, according to the National Institute for Early Education Research. Factors affecting eligibility include qualifying for a free- or reduced-price lunch, homelessness, or the inability to speak or comprehend English.
Texas children take mandated state tests: Wendy Davis claims that Greg Abbott seeks to impose tests on four-year-olds as well. The State of Texas Assessments of Academic Readiness (STAAR) is currently taken by Texas pupils, and Davis alleges that under Abbott, even four-year-olds would be forced to undergo standardized tests.
Clash over competing pre: kindergarten education proposals: Davis and Abbott have clashed over their competing proposals for pre-kindergarten education. Davis supports a broad expansion of full-day pre-K to all youngsters, costing the state about $750 million a year. In contrast, Abbott proposes spending an additional $1,500 per student in school districts that agree to implement a "gold standard" program consisting of a rigorous curriculum and staff requirements, along with assessments to measure the effectiveness of the pre-K programs.
Abbott: s education proposal discusses pre-K students being given standardized tests: Davis' campaign charges that Abbott wants to test four-year-olds based on the assessments mentioned in his education proposal. The proposal suggests that school districts with pre-kindergarten programs should administer assessments at the beginning and end of the school year to provide the Commissioner of Education with the necessary data to evaluate the programs effectively.
